Do not start implementation beads that depend on this track until the artifacts are explicit and approved.

Required artifacts from this track must be referenced directly in downstream PRs/tests to prevent interpretation drift.

title: ADR: define dual-mode invariants (MCP default, CLI opt-in)
description:
Background:
We need a durable contract for dual-mode behavior to prevent ambiguous implementation choices.

Deliverables:
- Formal invariants for MCP mode (default) vs CLI mode (opt-in).
- Exact definition of what "mode" controls (routing, parser behavior, help text, exit semantics).
- Explicit non-goals (no silent auto-switching, no implicit fallback between modes).

Definition of done:
ADR accepted and referenced by all downstream implementation beads.
close_reason: done

title: Spec: MCP-mode CLI denial UX contract and exit-code policy
description:
Background:
The denial UX is a product surface and must be deterministic, not ad-hoc.

Deliverables:
- Canonical denial phrase (e.g., "Agent Mail is not a CLI!").
- Exit code policy and stderr/stdout policy.
- Required remediation hints (how to enable CLI mode or use MCP path).
- Tone/verbosity requirements for agent-facing workflows.

Definition of done:
A signed-off denial UX spec consumable by implementation and snapshot tests.
close_reason: done

title: Spec: MCP-mode meta-command allowlist
description:
Background:
Even in MCP mode we likely need a tiny set of meta commands (help/version/config) to stay operable.

Deliverables:
- Enumerated allowlist for commands permitted when MCP mode is ON.
- Rationale per allowed command.
- Security/usability tradeoff analysis.

Definition of done:
Allowlist artifact ready for guard implementation and tests.
close_reason: done

title: Spec: MCP-to-CLI parity target matrix
description:
Background:
The request asks for an equivalent CLI command surface; we need an explicit parity target before implementation.

Deliverables:
- Mapping of MCP tools/resources/macros to CLI commands/subcommands.
- Gap labels: exact parity, partial parity, intentionally out-of-scope.
- Prioritization notes for agent-first workflows.

Definition of done:
Parity matrix published and linked by all CLI implementation beads.
close_reason: done

title: Track: Configuration + runtime mode-resolution foundation
description: Background: mode switching must be deterministic and shared across binaries. Deliverables: config flag semantics, precedence rules, mode resolver, diagnostics visibility, and invalid-combination checks.
design: Build a core resolver + config precedence model so mode behavior is deterministic and reusable across binaries and future surfaces.
acceptance_criteria: Config switch defaults correctly; resolver is shared; mode visibility appears in diagnostics/startup; conflicting mode inputs fail fast with actionable errors.
notes: This track is intentionally infrastructure-heavy because all denial/permitted behavior depends on resolver correctness.
close_reason: done

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Track 2 intent: one resolver, one truth.

Implementation principle:
- No per-command ad-hoc mode logic.
- Resolver provenance must be visible in diagnostics to simplify support incidents.

If resolver behavior changes, update Track 5 tests first to preserve trust boundaries.

title: Implement config switch for CLI mode (default OFF) with precedence rules
description:
Background:
Mode switching requires one explicit setting that is OFF by default for CLI mode.

Deliverables:
- Introduce and document config key(s) for enabling CLI mode (default false).
- Define precedence across env/config/flags.
- Define backward-compat behavior for existing deployments.

Definition of done:
Config schema updated with deterministic precedence and tests-in-waiting references.
close_reason: done

title: Implement shared InterfaceModeResolver in core
description:
Background:
Mode decisions must not be duplicated across binaries.

Deliverables:
- Shared `InterfaceModeResolver` (or equivalent) in core layer.
- Resolver returns normalized enum + provenance (where mode came from).
- Deterministic behavior under missing/conflicting settings.

Definition of done:
Both binaries can call one resolver and get identical decisions.
close_reason: done

title: Expose resolved interface mode in startup + diagnostics surfaces
description:
Background:
Operators need immediate visibility into active mode and why it was chosen.

Deliverables:
- Surface resolved mode in startup summary output.
- Surface resolved mode in config display/diagnostics endpoints.
- Ensure data is available for support/debug workflows.

Definition of done:
Mode observability is visible in all startup + diagnostics pathways.
close_reason: done

title: Add hard validation for conflicting mode inputs
description:
Background:
Invalid combinations (e.g., conflicting flags) should fail early and explicitly.

Deliverables:
- Validation rules for contradictory mode-related arguments/settings.
- Clear error messages that tell users what to change.

Definition of done:
No silent fallback on contradictory mode input.
close_reason: done

title: Track: MCP-mode CLI denial path and guardrails
description: Background: default MCP mode must reject CLI flows with a precise, consistent UX. Deliverables: pre-dispatch gate, denial renderer, allowed meta-command path, and comprehensive tests.
design: Centralized gate before command dispatch in am. Guard behavior references policy artifacts from Track 1 and resolver outputs from Track 2.
acceptance_criteria: Non-allowlisted CLI invocations in MCP mode are denied consistently; allowlisted meta commands work; output and exit codes are stable and test-covered.
notes: The guard is deliberately centralized to reduce bypass risk and to keep policy logic out of individual command handlers.
close_reason: done

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Track 3 intent: fail-safe default posture.

Guardrail principle:
- Deny by default in MCP mode; explicitly allow only approved meta commands.
- Error text and exit code are API-level contracts for automation.

Any variance in message/exit behavior should be treated as a breaking change and tested via snapshots.

title: Implement centralized MCP-mode CLI gate in am
description:
Background:
MCP mode must block CLI command execution at a single choke point.

Deliverables:
- Pre-dispatch guard in `am` command path.
- Guard references resolver output rather than ad-hoc checks.
- Guard only allows commands from the approved MCP-mode allowlist.

Definition of done:
CLI execution is impossible in MCP mode except approved meta commands.
close_reason: done

title: Implement canonical denial renderer: 'Agent Mail is not a CLI!'
description:
Background:
The denial response is part of product UX and must be consistent everywhere.

Deliverables:
- Canonical renderer for denial message and hints.
- Stable wording and formatting suitable for humans and agents.
- Stable exit behavior.

Definition of done:
All blocked CLI invocations produce the same contract-compliant output.
close_reason: done

title: Wire MCP-mode allowlisted meta commands through guard
description:
Background:
Usability requires that essential introspection commands still work in MCP mode.

Deliverables:
- Wire allowlisted meta commands through guard path.
- Verify non-allowlisted commands are denied.
- Provide explicit docs and hints for why behavior differs.

Definition of done:
Allowlist behavior exactly matches policy artifact.
close_reason: done

title: Test suite for MCP-mode denial path (unit + integration + snapshots)
description:
Background:
Guardrails regress quickly unless denial-path behavior is locked by focused tests.

Deliverables:
- Unit tests for guard decision matrix and allowlisted meta-command routing.
- Integration tests for nested subcommand denial decisions at the command-dispatch boundary.
- Focused snapshots for denial renderer output (message text, exit semantics, stream placement).

Non-overlap boundary:
This bead is component-level denial-path validation only; full cross-command matrix/e2e behavior belongs to br-21gj.5.2 and br-21gj.5.6.

Definition of done:
Any accidental CLI enablement in MCP mode is caught immediately with high-signal failures.
notes: Produces denial-path fixtures consumed by higher-level matrix/e2e layers; avoids duplicate end-to-end scenario expansion.
close_reason: done

title: Track: CLI-mode command parity implementation (agent-first ergonomics)
description: Background: when CLI mode is enabled, operators expect a coherent command surface approximating MCP capability with agent-first UX. Deliverables: command framework and domain command groups for identity/project, messaging, reservations, contacts/acks, macros, and diagnostics.
design: Implement CLI command families in modular groups using one framework and one output/error contract, guided by parity matrix and agent-first UX constraints.
acceptance_criteria: Each command family is implemented with parity evidence, consistent UX, and closure audit confirming no untracked gaps.
notes: Families are separable for parallel execution; dependencies enforce foundation first, then domain groups, then closure audit.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Track 4 intent: implement parity in cohesive command families with consistent ergonomics.

Work sequencing:
- 4.1 first, then parallel family implementation, then 4.8 closure audit.

Ergonomics rule:
- Every family should expose clear human output and machine JSON output with predictable structure and remediation hints.

title: Build shared CLI command framework for CLI mode
description:
Background:
Command parity work will fragment unless we standardize command architecture first.

Deliverables:
- Shared handler conventions and error model for CLI-mode command families.
- Shared argument normalization and output adapter hooks.
- Agent-first ergonomics baseline (naming, defaults, predictable structure).

Definition of done:
All subsequent command-family beads build on a common framework.

title: CLI parity: identity/project/product command family
description:
Background:
Identity/project/product flows are foundational for all other operations.

Deliverables:
- Agent identity and project/product command surface in CLI mode.
- Consistent output and error semantics.
- Alignment with parity matrix target.

Definition of done:
Identity and project/product flows are first-class in CLI mode.

title: CLI parity: messaging/thread/search command family
description:
Background:
Messaging/thread workflows are central to agent coordination and must be ergonomic.

Deliverables:
- CLI-mode message send/reply/fetch/search/thread commands.
- Thread-centric, agent-first defaults where safe.
- Behavior aligned with MCP semantics per parity matrix.

Definition of done:
Core messaging workflows are usable end-to-end in CLI mode.

title: CLI parity: file-reservation lifecycle command family
description:
Background:
File reservations are central to multi-agent safety and must be reliable under conflict-heavy workflows.

Deliverables:
- CLI-mode commands for reservation create/renew/release/list/conflict introspection.
- Explicit TTL/exclusive semantics and deterministic conflict output.
- Clear ownership/context surfaces (agent, reason, expiry, overlap holder list).

Validation requirements:
- Unit tests for TTL parsing, overlap detection, exclusive/shared rules, and renewal boundaries.
- Integration matrix rows in br-21gj.5.2 covering MCP-mode denial and CLI-mode allow behavior for reservation commands.
- Script-level e2e traces in br-21gj.5.6 with structured per-command logs.

Definition of done:
Reservation lifecycle is complete, predictable, and diagnosable for operators and agents.
notes: Non-overlap: this bead owns reservation command implementation only; semantic parity assertions and broad e2e orchestration are owned by br-21gj.5.3 and br-21gj.5.6.
close_reason: Implemented Reserve/Renew/Release/Conflicts subcommands with full SQL handlers, conflict detection, TTL enforcement, and 23 tests (11 clap parsing + 9 integration + 3 existing)

title: CLI parity: contact + acknowledgement command family
description:
Background:
Contact approvals and acknowledgement flows are policy-sensitive and easy to regress.

Deliverables:
- CLI-mode contact request/approve/reject/policy command coverage.
- CLI-mode ack/mark-read flows with deterministic pending/fulfilled state transitions.
- Clear error contracts for blocked contacts, missing links, and stale ack-required messages.

Validation requirements:
- Unit tests for state transitions and policy edge cases.
- Integration matrix rows in br-21gj.5.2 for MCP-deny/CLI-allow behavior.
- E2E script traces in br-21gj.5.6 including acknowledgement timelines and failure bundles.

Definition of done:
Contact and acknowledgement workflows match policy intent and are operationally debuggable.
notes: Non-overlap: this bead implements contact/ack command behavior; cross-surface semantic conformance and perf/security gating are in br-21gj.5.3 and br-21gj.5.4.

title: CLI parity: macro command family
description:
Background:
Macro commands are a productivity multiplier and must be first-class in CLI mode.

Deliverables:
- CLI-mode macro support for session/thread/file-reservation/contact workflows.
- Agent-first defaults with explicit override visibility to avoid hidden behavior.
- Macro output contracts that are both human-readable and machine-consumable.

Validation requirements:
- Unit tests for macro argument normalization, defaulting, and override precedence.
- Integration matrix rows in br-21gj.5.2 for macro invocation in both interface modes.
- E2E scripts in br-21gj.5.6 with step-by-step macro expansion logs and reproduction commands.

Definition of done:
Macro workflows are practical, deterministic, and traceable in CLI mode.
notes: Non-overlap: macro implementation only; parity closure/accounting is handled by br-21gj.4.8 and semantic conformance by br-21gj.5.3.
close_reason: done

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text: Implemented all 4 macro CLI commands (start-session, prepare-thread, file-reservation-cycle, contact-handshake) with full arg parsing, async handlers using DB queries directly, and 12 unit tests covering minimal + all-flags parsing and help text. All tests pass.

title: CLI parity: tooling + diagnostics command family
description:
Background:
Tooling/diagnostics commands are essential for support, automation, and operator confidence.

Deliverables:
- CLI-mode commands for tooling directory/schemas/metrics/locks and diagnostics-equivalent views.
- Stable JSON output options for automation and CI consumption.
- Actionable help text that points to next troubleshooting steps.

Validation requirements:
- Unit tests for output schema stability and argument validation.
- Integration matrix rows in br-21gj.5.2 confirming mode-gated behavior.
- E2E script coverage in br-21gj.5.6 with artifact capture for diagnostic command failures.

Definition of done:
Diagnostics/tooling workflows are discoverable, scriptable, and stable across mode changes.
notes: Non-overlap: this bead implements tooling command surface only; release/readiness checks remain in br-21gj.6.4.

comments.author: RedHarbor
comments.text: Started implementation. Fixed tooling/diagnostics wiring regressions in CLI: updated handler field mappings to current core metrics/lock schemas and validated command execution. Validation status: cargo check --all-targets PASS, cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings PASS, cargo fmt --check reports unrelated pre-existing diff in crates/mcp-agent-mail-core/src/config.rs. Smoke verified: am tooling directory --json, am tooling diagnostics --json, am macros --help.

title: Parity closure audit for all CLI command families
description:
Background:
Parity implementation needs explicit closure so no command family is silently omitted.

Deliverables:
- Audit checklist mapping every parity-matrix row to an implemented command or explicit defer/out-of-scope rationale.
- Cross-link evidence to implementation beads and validation artifacts.
- Gap register with owner and follow-up bead IDs for any accepted deferrals.

Non-overlap boundary:
This is an implementation-coverage audit, not a behavioral test suite. Runtime validation belongs to br-21gj.5.x.

Definition of done:
No hidden parity gaps remain, and every omission is intentional, documented, and traceable.
notes: Canonical parity-coverage ledger consumed by docs and rollout tracks.

title: Track: Validation, conformance, performance, and security
description: Background: dual-mode behavior is high-risk without deep validation. Deliverables: unit/integration/conformance/perf/security test suites that prove mode correctness and prevent regressions.
design: Canonical validation pipeline: (1) unit resolver/guard invariants, (2) integration + e2e mode matrix harness, (3) semantic conformance assertions against MCP behavior, (4) perf/security regressions, (5) golden snapshots + CI artifact retention. Each stage consumes the previous stage outputs to avoid duplicated test logic and drift.
acceptance_criteria: 1) Unit coverage exists for resolver/precedence/conflict logic. 2) Integration matrix and shell e2e scripts exercise MCP-ON deny + CLI-ON allow paths with detailed structured logs and reproducible artifacts. 3) Conformance assertions verify CLI semantics match MCP tool semantics for supported operations. 4) Perf/security regressions are measured and enforced. 5) Snapshot contracts and CI artifact retention make failures diagnosable without reruns.
notes: Overlap-control rule: child beads in this track must define explicit non-overlap boundaries and reuse shared harnesses/artifacts rather than re-implementing scenario logic.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Track 5 intent: quality gate, not optional cleanup.

Blocking policy:
- Track 6 rollout/docs should not be marked complete until 5.2/5.3/5.4 pass.

Validation focus:
- Correctness (mode behavior), semantic parity (CLI vs MCP), and abuse resistance (bypass attempts).

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text: Planning consolidation note (2026-02-08): de-overlapped validation into explicit pipeline stages. Canonical flow is now br-21gj.5.1 (unit invariants) -> br-21gj.5.2 (integration+e2e matrix harness with structured logs) -> br-21gj.5.3 (semantic conformance) -> br-21gj.5.4 (perf/security regressions) with br-21gj.5.5 (text contract snapshots), br-21gj.5.6 (rich e2e scripts/artifacts), and br-21gj.5.7 (CI gating + artifact retention). This avoids repeated scenario logic across beads while improving diagnosability.

title: Unit tests: mode resolver, precedence, and invariants
description:
Background:
Mode behavior correctness starts with resolver/guard invariants and fast deterministic tests.

Deliverables:
- Unit tests for mode defaults, precedence, and conflicting input handling.
- Unit tests for allowlist/deny decision helpers with explicit edge-case tables.
- Structured unit-test diagnostics for failing invariants (showing mode source/provenance and selected policy path).

Definition of done:
Core mode semantics are locked by fast deterministic tests with high-signal failure logs.
notes: Fastest feedback layer in validation pipeline; upstream dependency for CI quality gates.
close_reason: done

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text: Implemented 28 unit tests for InterfaceModeResolver, mode precedence, and invariants in config.rs. Tests cover: InterfaceMode helpers (default, is_mcp, is_cli, display, equality), ModeProvenance display, ResolvedMode display, explicit override precedence, env var override precedence, binary default fallback, validate() conflict detection, precedence invariants (explicit > env > binary default), and edge cases (same-as-default override, empty env var, validate with explicit override). Refactored resolve()/validate() to use internal resolve_with_env()/validate_with_env() methods for safe testing without process env mutation (respects #![forbid(unsafe_code)]). All tests pass, clippy clean.

title: Integration + e2e matrix harness: MCP-deny vs CLI-allow with structured logs
description:
Background:
Mode toggling behavior must be proven end-to-end across representative command families and invocation contexts.

Deliverables:
- Shared matrix harness covering MCP mode deny paths and CLI mode allow paths.
- Rust integration tests plus shell e2e scripts that execute the same matrix rows.
- Structured logs per test row: mode, command, expected decision, actual decision, exit code, stderr/stdout digest.
- Artifact output format for later conformance/perf/security stages.

Non-overlap boundary:
This bead validates routing/decision behavior and invocation mechanics only. Semantic equivalence assertions belong to br-21gj.5.3.

Definition of done:
Matrix harness is reusable and produces deterministic, richly logged artifacts for downstream validation stages.
notes: Canonical source of truth for dual-mode scenario matrix and shared test harness artifacts.

title: Semantic conformance suite on top of matrix harness
description:
Background:
After routing behavior is proven, we need semantic parity evidence for supported operations.

Deliverables:
- Conformance assertions that compare CLI-mode outcomes against MCP-tool outcomes for the parity matrix.
- Explicit checks for success paths, validation failures, and policy-denied paths.
- Drift report format identifying exact mismatches by operation and field.

Non-overlap boundary:
This bead does NOT rebuild matrix execution plumbing; it consumes artifacts/harnesses from br-21gj.5.2.

Definition of done:
Conformance suite demonstrates semantic alignment or documents justified exceptions with explicit rationale.
notes: Consumes br-21gj.5.2 outputs; no duplicate scenario execution logic.

title: Performance + security regressions on conformance-validated surface
description:
Background:
Perf/security gates should run after behavioral and semantic correctness are established.

Deliverables:
- Regression checks for dispatch latency and hot-path behavior on the validated command surface.
- Security tests for mode-bypass attempts, malformed mode inputs, and denial-guard evasion attempts.
- Detailed benchmark/security logs keyed by matrix operation identifiers.

Non-overlap boundary:
This bead does not define semantic expectations; it enforces SLO/security constraints on the surface already validated by br-21gj.5.3.

Definition of done:
No significant regressions, bypass attempts are blocked, and evidence is captured in reproducible logs/artifacts.
notes: Gate runs after conformance; security/perf signals are tied back to matrix operation IDs for triage.

title: Golden snapshots for denial/help/usage contracts
description:
Background:
Textual UX contracts drift silently unless snapshots are managed as first-class artifacts.

Deliverables:
- Golden snapshots for MCP-deny messaging, mode-specific help, and usage output.
- Snapshot diff tooling/output conventions for fast triage.
- Snapshot review checklist to distinguish intentional UX updates from regressions.

Non-overlap boundary:
This bead focuses on textual contract stability only; behavioral correctness remains in br-21gj.5.2/5.3/5.4 and br-21gj.3.4.

Definition of done:
Output contract drift is automatically caught and diagnosable from snapshot artifacts.
notes: Text-contract lock layer; intentionally separate from semantic/perf/security layers.
close_reason: Golden snapshot system implemented: 3 new tests (golden_denial_message_format_contract: 5 denial messages validated against canonical format + fixtures, golden_cli_help_snapshot_stability: 6 help outputs saved as golden fixtures, golden_usage_error_format: 2 usage error cases). Snapshots in tests/fixtures/golden_snapshots/ (11 files). bench_golden.sh expanded with denial capture + additional CLI help. Fixed 2 pre-existing clippy issues in cli lib.rs.

title: Dual-mode e2e script suite with rich structured logging
description:
Background:
We need shell-level, operator-realistic validation beyond Rust integration tests.

Deliverables:
- New e2e scripts for dual-mode behavior (MCP default deny + CLI opt-in allow) covering all parity command families.
- Rich per-step logs: timestamp, mode source/provenance, command, expected vs actual decision, stderr/stdout excerpts, exit code.
- Failure bundle artifacts (raw output, normalized summary, reproduction command).
- Deterministic log formatting for CI diffability.

Definition of done:
A single commandable e2e suite can reproduce mode bugs with actionable logs in one run.
notes: Canonical script-level e2e layer. Must produce detailed structured logs (mode provenance, command, expectation, decision, exit code, output digests), plus failure bundles with one-command repro instructions. Non-overlap: avoids redefining semantic assertions already covered in br-21gj.5.3.

title: CI quality gates + artifact retention for unit/integration/conformance/e2e logs
description:
Background:
Validation only helps if CI enforces it and preserves enough evidence for fast triage.

Deliverables:
- CI wiring that runs unit, integration, conformance, perf/security, and new dual-mode e2e suites.
- Standardized artifact upload: matrix logs, conformance drift reports, perf/security summaries, snapshot diffs.
- Failure summary format that points directly to failing mode/command scenario and reproduction command.
- Guardrails to prevent silent test-skip regressions.

Definition of done:
CI gates dual-mode changes with reproducible artifact trails sufficient for single-pass debugging.
notes: CI gatekeeper layer. Must enforce execution of unit/integration/conformance/perf/e2e suites and publish durable artifacts for every failing scenario. Include anti-regression checks for accidental test skipping and artifact schema drift.

title: Track: Documentation, rollout, migration, and operations
description: Background: behavior changes affect operators and automated agents. Deliverables: docs updates, migration guide, rollout/kill-switch playbook, and post-release monitoring checklist.
design: Operationalization track converts implementation into safe adoption: docs, migration guidance, staged rollout, fallback strategy, and monitoring loop.
acceptance_criteria: All operator docs updated; migration playbook published; rollout/kill-switch plan approved; release/post-release checklists include mode-specific verifications.
notes: This track ensures the feature is supportable in production and that future teams can operate it without relying on tribal knowledge.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone

Track 6 intent: make the change operable and supportable.

Operational expectations:
- Docs must state MCP default clearly and show explicit CLI mode enablement.
- Migration guidance must include script/automation examples.

Dual-mode changes must be operable without institutional memory.

Operator documentation is internally consistent, executable, and tied to validated behavior.

Dual-mode rollout needs explicit operational controls to avoid user-visible incidents.

title: Release checklist + post-release monitoring checklist updates

Release quality depends on explicit verification and post-release monitoring discipline.

title: Share: search indexes + materialized views + perf indexes
description:
## Objective
Implement share pipeline Steps 4–6: FTS5 search indexes, materialized views, and performance indexes for static viewer.

## Scope
- **build_search_indexes**: create `fts_messages` virtual table; populate with subject/body/importance/project/thread_key/created_ts; optimize.
- **build_materialized_views**: create `message_overview_mv`, `attachments_by_message_mv`, `fts_search_overview_mv` (if FTS enabled).
- **create_performance_indexes**: add lowercase columns and covering indexes for fast viewer filtering.

## Tests
- Unit tests for FTS presence/absence path.

title: MCP tools: send_message/thread_id causes timeouts and server becomes unreachable
description:
## Observed
Tool calls to the local MCP Agent Mail HTTP server became unreachable after calling `send_message` with a `thread_id` (and even without).

Symptoms:
- `send_message(..., thread_id="br-threadid-test")` timed out (60s).
- Subsequent tool calls (`fetch_inbox`, `whois`, `health_check`) timed out or failed with transport send errors to `http://127.0.0.1:8765/mcp/`.

## Hypotheses
- Deadlock or long-running operation inside `send_message` (DB transaction held, git/archive write, attachment conversion) causing request handler starvation.
- Panic/crash in tool handler when `thread_id` is set (or on created_ts formatting), bringing down HTTP server.

## Repro Steps
1. Start server: `cargo run -p mcp-agent-mail -- serve --host 127.0.0.1 --port 8765`.
2. Call `send_message(project_key="/data/projects/mcp_agent_mail_rust", sender_name="RusticGlen", to=["RusticGlen"], subject="...", body_md="...", thread_id="br-threadid-test")`.
3. Observe whether request completes; then call `health_check` / `fetch_inbox`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `send_message` returns promptly for trivial messages (no attachments) regardless of `thread_id`.
- Server remains responsive after `send_message`.
- Add a regression test (unit or conformance) that fails fast on handler stalls/panics.

title: Storage: Git archive write/read pipeline + attachments
description:
Implement the git-backed mailbox archive described in EXISTING_MCP_AGENT_MAIL_STRUCTURE.md.

Legacy Python writes messages + file reservations + attachments into a per-project git repo and uses it as an auditable artifact store.

Scope (must match legacy behavior):
- Archive root creation + .gitattributes
- Per-project advisory locks (.archive.lock + owner metadata)
- Commit batching queue (max 10, max wait 50ms)
- Message write pipeline:
  - canonical messages/YYYY/MM/*.md
  - agents/<Agent>/inbox + outbox copies
  - thread digest files (messages/threads/<thread_id>.md) if present in legacy
  - git commit message format
- File reservation artifacts (file_reservations/<sha1(pattern)>.json + id-<id>.json)
- Attachment pipeline:
  - compute content hashes
  - convert images to WebP when enabled
  - inline small attachments (< 64KiB) into markdown
  - keep originals when configured
  - write manifests + audit logs
- Read helpers for resources that include commit metadata.

Constraints:
- Prefer git2 library; avoid shelling out when possible.
- Prefer asupersync for IO/concurrency.

## Success Criteria
1. Artifact conformance (br-2ei.1.3) can assert archive artifacts match legacy (layout + frontmatter + body + attachment manifests).
2. E2E archive suite (br-2ei.9.2) passes and produces rich artifacts/logs.
3. Benchmarks include archive write throughput and lock/commit batching overhead budgets.
4. No cross-process corruption: advisory locks are cross-platform and stale-lock recovery is safe.

title: Reservations: implement force_release_file_reservation (inactivity heuristics + optional notify)
description:
Implement force-release stale file reservations (MCP tool).

Spec:
- Validate reservation appears abandoned:
  - agent inactive beyond threshold
  - no recent mail activity
  - no recent filesystem/git activity (archive)
- When released, optionally notify previous holder with a human-readable note.

Implementation plan:
- Define which activity signals we can reliably measure in Rust:
  - `agent.last_active_ts` in DB
  - last message activity timestamps (inbox/outbox/canonical)
  - archive activity timestamps (last commit touching agent/mail artifacts)
- Implement heuristics with conservative defaults and an explicit “why” explanation string.
- Write release to DB + archive artifacts (so humans can audit forced releases).
- If `notify_previous=true`: send a threaded message to the previous holder explaining the forced release and including the heuristics snapshot.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Safety / correctness:
  - Force-release is denied unless heuristics strongly indicate abandonment (tests cover deny path).
  - When allowed, release updates both DB state and archive artifacts (tests assert both).
  - No-op behavior when reservation already released/expired is well-defined.
- Observability:
  - Tool output includes a machine-parseable explanation (what signals were checked + thresholds + timestamps used).
  - Optional notify message includes the explanation and the operator’s note.
- Conformance:
  - Fixture-based conformance tests cover at least: allow path, deny path, and allow-with-notify path.
- Tests:
  - Unit tests cover heuristic evaluation boundary conditions (just-below/just-above thresholds).
  - Integration test runs through the full tool pipeline and validates resulting archive messages + reservation state.

Guard: pre-commit/pre-push enforcement + install/uninstall tooling
description:
Implement the Agent Mail guard system (pre-commit / pre-push hooks) that prevents edits when exclusive file reservations conflict.

Spec source:
- EXISTING_MCP_AGENT_MAIL_STRUCTURE.md section "Guard Behavior (Pre-Commit / Pre-Push)"

Scope:
- `mcp-agent-mail-guard` crate:
  - install_guard(project, repo): resolves hooks dir (core.hooksPath or default), writes chain-runner hooks, writes plugin scripts under hooks.d/<hook>.
  - uninstall_guard(repo): removes our plugins; removes chain-runner only if safe (no other plugins) and restores .orig if applicable.
  - guard_status(repo): reports resolved hooks path + presence of pre-commit/pre-push + mode.
  - guard_check(repo, paths, advisory): checks active file reservations and returns conflicts (pattern, holder, expires_ts).
- MCP tools:
  - install_precommit_guard(project_key, code_repo_path)
  - uninstall_precommit_guard(code_repo_path)
- CLI wiring:
  - `am guard install|uninstall|status|check` delegates to the guard crate.

Implementation notes:
- Use git2 to discover repo + read config.
- Path matching: prefer pathspec (gitignore syntax) with symmetric fnmatch fallback.
- Must respect env vars: AGENT_MAIL_GUARD_MODE, AGENT_MAIL_BYPASS, AGENT_NAME.

## Success Criteria
1. Guard tool outputs match legacy fixtures (install/uninstall/status/check).
2. Unit + integration tests cover: hooksPath/worktrees, idempotent install/uninstall, path matching, rename handling, conflict detection.
3. E2E guard suite (br-2ei.9.3) blocks commits on conflicts and allows after release, with clear stderr and rich artifacts.

description:
Implement robust hooks directory resolution.

  - Else: use default hooks dir for the repository common dir.

title: Guard: install/uninstall chain-runner hooks + agent-mail plugin scripts
description:
Implement install/uninstall mechanics (pre-commit and optionally pre-push).

Install behavior (match legacy):
- Ensure hooks.d/<hook>/ directory exists.
- Write/overwrite top-level hook script (chain-runner) that executes hooks.d/<hook>/* in lexical order.
- Preserve existing non-chain hook as <hook>.orig.
- Install our plugin under hooks.d/<hook>/50-agent-mail (or equivalent) that executes the actual guard check.
- Create Windows shims (.cmd/.ps1) if needed to invoke the chain-runner.

Uninstall behavior:
- Remove our plugins (hooks.d/<hook>/50-agent-mail.*).
- Only remove chain-runner if it is ours AND there are no other plugins remaining AND no .orig restoration is needed.
- If .orig exists and chain-runner is removed, restore it.

Deliverables:
- `install_guard(project_key, repo)` writes files and chmods +x on unix.
- `uninstall_guard(repo)` removes/restores safely.
- Unit tests use temp git repos.
close_reason: Implemented install_guard/uninstall_guard: resolves hooks dir, installs python chain-runner + Windows shims, installs plugin stub, preserves/restores existing hook via .orig; added unit test for preserve/restore.

title: Guard: implement conflict detection (reservations + path matching + rename handling)
description:
Implement the actual guard decision logic.

Inputs:
- repo path
- list of paths to check (from staged diff for pre-commit, from commit range for pre-push)
- AGENT_NAME env var identifies current agent
- mode: block vs warn (AGENT_MAIL_GUARD_MODE)
- bypass env: AGENT_MAIL_BYPASS=1

Logic:
- If guard disabled (WORKTREES_ENABLED or GIT_IDENTITY_ENABLED false): allow.
- Load active file reservations for the project identity associated with repo (project_identity_mode logic).
- If any exclusive reservation matches any path (symmetric matching) and reservation holder != AGENT_NAME and unexpired: conflict.
- For renames: treat both old and new paths as touched.

Deliverables:
- Pure function that returns conflicts (pattern, holder, expires_ts) for a given path list.
- Helper to obtain staged paths from git: `git diff --cached --name-only -z --diff-filter=ACMRDTU` and rename pairs from `--name-status -M -z`.
- Helper to obtain pre-push paths from stdin refs (`git rev-list`) with fallback to `git diff --name-status -M -z <remote>..<local>`.

Tests:
- Synthetic reservations + path lists.
- Temp repo with staged rename.

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Guard conflict detection matches legacy behavior for:
   - exclusive vs shared reservations
   - holder == AGENT_NAME bypass
   - expired/released reservations
   - rename pairs (old + new paths considered touched)
2. Unit tests cover synthetic and real-repo staged rename scenarios.
3. Hook output is clear enough that the E2E guard suite can assert expected failure messaging.

title: Share/Export: static bundle pipeline (SQLite snapshot + scrub + attachments + signing/encryption)

1. CLI share commands work end-to-end and match legacy behavior where specified.
2. Bundle output is deterministic for identical inputs (stable ordering + hashing).

title: Upstream dependency: asupersync Http1Request.peer_addr
description:
This repo needs accurate client peer address (SocketAddr) on each HTTP request to match legacy Python behavior for:
- localhost bypass (allow_localhost_unauthenticated)
- bearer token injection for base-path passthrough
- rate limit identity derivation (host when JWT sub missing)

Upstream work lives in /dp/asupersync.

Required API surface (asupersync):
1. Expose the remote peer address on Http1Request (or equivalent request context):
   - Prefer: `Http1Request.peer_addr: Option<SocketAddr>` (or accessor)
   - Must be present even when no forwarded headers are set
2. Ensure forwarded headers do NOT overwrite peer_addr (legacy uses actual client host for localhost checks).
3. Maintain tokio-free surface (asupersync conventions).

Downstream work (this repo):
- Update mcp-agent-mail-server to read peer_addr and derive client_host string, including IPv4-mapped IPv6 handling.
- Wire into localhost detection helper + rate limit identity.

External references:
- asupersync beads created by another agent: bd-32eba (and children) (prefix may be corrected later).

## Acceptance Criteria
1. /dp/asupersync exposes peer_addr in the HTTP request type used by mcp-agent-mail-server.
2. This repo can compile against the updated asupersync without tokio.
3. br-1bm.3.1 can be implemented using this API with no hacks.
close_reason: Added Http1Request.peer_addr and wired through Http1Server/Listener (asupersync)

title: E2E: guard enforcement in temp git repo (pre-commit + renames)
description:
End-to-end verification of the guard system in a real temp git repo.

Script:
- scripts/e2e_guard.sh

Flow:
1. Create a temp git repo with a tracked file.
2. Install the agent-mail guard (via CLI `am guard install` or MCP tool).
3. Create an exclusive file reservation held by another agent for the file (or a matching pattern).
4. Modify + stage the file, attempt `git commit`:
   - Expected: blocked (non-zero), stderr contains clear conflict info.
5. Release the reservation and retry commit:
   - Expected: allowed.
6. Rename scenario:
   - Create reservation matching old/new path; stage rename; ensure guard checks both sides.
7. stdin-nul + ignorecase:
   - run guard check with --stdin-nul input (NUL-delimited paths) and verify correct conflict detection.
   - set core.ignorecase true and verify case-insensitive match behavior matches legacy.

Logging/artifacts:
- Capture hook output, git status/diff summaries, and reservation records.
- Store under tests/artifacts/guard/<timestamp>/.

Safety:
- Operate only within temp dirs.
- Never run destructive git/fs commands.

## Acceptance Criteria
1. scripts/e2e_guard.sh runs via scripts/e2e_test.sh guard.
2. Script demonstrates a blocked commit when an exclusive reservation conflicts, including clear stderr output.
3. Script demonstrates an allowed commit after reservation release.

title: E2E: share/export bundle (manifest + DB + attachments + determinism)
description:

Flow:

2. Run `am share export` (or equivalent) to produce a bundle directory.

   - Run export twice from same inputs; compare stable hashes of key outputs (manifest + DB + attachment manifests).
5. Preview + verify subcommands:
   - Run `am share preview` on the bundle and assert expected summary fields.
   - Run `am share verify` (or equivalent) and assert success for valid bundle.
   - Corrupt manifest/attachment reference and assert `verify` fails with clear error.
6. Signing/encryption (when enabled):
   - Run signed export and verify signature.
   - Run encrypted export and verify decrypt roundtrip.

Logging/artifacts:
- Dump bundle tree + sizes, log PRAGMA results, and hashes.
- Store under tests/artifacts/share/<timestamp>/.

Exit criteria:
- Any mismatch -> non-zero.

## Acceptance Criteria
1. scripts/e2e_share.sh runs via scripts/e2e_test.sh share.
2. Script produces tests/artifacts/share/<timestamp>/ including bundle tree, PRAGMA results, and hashes.
3. Script asserts manifest/db/attachments consistency and fails on missing referenced paths.
4. Script asserts deterministic output across two runs from identical inputs (documented hash set).
5. Preview/verify subcommands are exercised and emit expected success/error semantics.
6. When signing/encryption are enabled, E2E validates signature and decrypt roundtrip using deterministic fixtures.

title: E2E tests for CORS preflight behavior (OPTIONS, headers, origin configs)
description:
Create tests/e2e/test_cors.sh that exercises CORS preflight and header behavior via HTTP requests against a running server.

## Test Cases (12+ assertions)

### Case 1: CORS disabled by default
- Start server without CORS env vars
- Send request with Origin header → response should NOT have Access-Control-Allow-Origin

### Case 2: CORS enabled with wildcard
- Start server with AM_CORS_ENABLED=true, AM_CORS_ORIGINS="" (empty = all)
- OPTIONS request with Origin: https://example.com → 200
- Response has Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
- Response has Access-Control-Allow-Methods header
- Response has Access-Control-Allow-Headers header

### Case 3: CORS with specific origins
- Start server with AM_CORS_ORIGINS=https://allowed.com
- Request from Origin: https://allowed.com → CORS headers present
- Request from Origin: https://denied.com → no CORS headers (or no allow-origin)

### Case 4: CORS with credentials
- Start server with AM_CORS_ALLOW_CREDENTIALS=true
- Wildcard origin config → should echo back actual Origin (not *) per spec
- Response has Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true

### Case 5: OPTIONS method handling
- OPTIONS on /mcp → returns CORS headers, 200 status, no body required
- OPTIONS on /healthz → verify behavior (health routes bypass CORS)

### Case 6: Non-OPTIONS requests with Origin
- POST /mcp with Origin header → CORS headers present on response
- Verify CORS headers on both success and error responses

## Logging & Quality
- Source e2e_lib.sh, e2e_case_banner per case
- Use e2e_assert_contains for header checks, e2e_assert_eq for status codes
- Log all curl -v output to artifact dir
- Multiple server restarts (different configs) — use e2e_find_free_port per restart

## Acceptance Criteria
- All assertions pass
- Tests config permutations: disabled, wildcard, specific origins, credentials
- Clean server shutdown between config changes

description:

### Case 1: Concurrent file reservation conflict
- Register 3 agents (GoldHawk, SilverFox, CoralPeak) in same project
- GoldHawk reserves "src/**" exclusively
- SilverFox tries to reserve "src/main.rs" → should get conflict (holders=[GoldHawk])
- CoralPeak tries to reserve "docs/**" → should succeed (no overlap)
- Verify conflict response includes GoldHawk's name and reservation ID

### Case 2: Reservation release unblocks others
- GoldHawk releases "src/**"
- SilverFox retries "src/main.rs" → should now succeed
- Verify granted response with new reservation ID

### Case 3: Concurrent message sending
- All 3 agents send messages to each other simultaneously (in background subshells)
- Wait for all to complete
- Verify each agent's inbox contains exactly the expected messages

### Case 4: Racing for same file reservation
- 3 agents all try to reserve "shared/config.toml" exclusively at the same time (background)

### Case 5: Interleaved read/write operations
- Agent A sends 10 messages in a loop
- Agent B fetches inbox after each send (polling)
- Agent C acknowledges messages as they arrive
- Verify final state: all 10 messages sent, all acknowledged
- Verify fetch_inbox returns monotonically increasing message IDs

### Case 6: Reservation TTL expiry
- GoldHawk reserves "expiry/test.rs" with ttl_seconds=2
- Immediately: SilverFox tries → conflict
- Sleep 3 seconds
- SilverFox retries → should succeed (TTL expired)

description:
Create tests/e2e/test_contact_policies.sh that exercises all 4 contact policies and their enforcement behavior.

## Background
Contact policies control who can message an agent: open (anyone), auto (approved or recent), contacts_only (explicitly approved only), block_all (nobody). These are set via set_contact_policy and enforced in send_message.

## Test Cases (15+ assertions)

### Case 1: Default policy (open)
- Register two agents, no policy set
- Agent A sends to Agent B → succeeds (default is open)
- Verify message in B's inbox

### Case 2: block_all policy
- Set Agent B policy to block_all
- Agent A sends to B → error with CONTACT_BLOCKED
- Verify error response contains clear reason
- Verify B's inbox is empty (no partial delivery)

### Case 3: contacts_only without approval
- Set Agent B policy to contacts_only
- Agent A (not approved) sends to B → blocked
- Verify error mentions contacts_only or approval needed

### Case 4: contacts_only with approval
- Agent A sends request_contact to B
- Agent B calls respond_contact accept=true
- Agent A sends to B → now succeeds
- Verify message delivered

### Case 5: auto policy — approved contact
- Set Agent B policy to auto
- Agent A has approved contact link with B
- Agent A sends → succeeds

### Case 6: auto policy — no contact
- Set Agent C policy to auto
- New agent (no contact history) sends to C → blocked
- Verify error or auto_contact_if_blocked behavior

### Case 7: auto_contact_if_blocked flag
- Agent A sends to B (blocked) with auto_contact_if_blocked=true
- Verify automatic contact request is created
- Verify B receives contact request in inbox

### Case 8: Policy change mid-session
- Agent B policy = open, Agent A sends → success
- Change B policy to block_all
- Agent A sends again → now blocked
- Verify policy change is immediately effective

### Case 9: Thread participants bypass (automatic allow-list)
- Agent B policy = contacts_only
- Agent B starts a thread (sends message to A)
- Agent A replies in same thread → should succeed (thread participant bypass)

### Case 10: Shared file reservation bypass
- Agent B policy = contacts_only
- Both A and B have overlapping file reservations
- Agent A sends to B → should succeed (shared reservation bypass)

## Logging & Quality
- Source e2e_lib.sh, e2e_case_banner per case
- Use stdio transport with single server process
- Log all JSON-RPC requests/responses to artifact dir
- Use e2e_assert_contains for error messages, e2e_assert_eq for status checks
- e2e_summary at end

## Acceptance Criteria
- All 4 policies tested with positive and negative cases
- Bypass rules (thread participants, shared reservations) verified
- auto_contact_if_blocked flow tested
- Policy changes take immediate effect
close_reason: done

title: Conformance harness hygiene: stop mutating tracked python_reference/_scratch archives
description:
Problem: The conformance fixture generator/harness has a python_reference/_scratch area that contains git archives. These directories are currently tracked in git and can be mutated by runs, leaving a dirty worktree. Even with .gitignore, tracked scratch dirs stay tracked, so any mutation creates noisy diffs and risks committing generated state.

Deliverables:
- Make conformance generation and test execution hermetic: any writable/scratch archives must be copied to a temp dir (e.g., via tempfile) before mutation. Never write into the committed fixture tree.
- Add an explicit regression test/guard: running conformance should not modify any files under crates/mcp-agent-mail-conformance/tests/conformance/python_reference (especially _scratch).
- Optionally (needs explicit permission for deletion): remove committed _scratch artifacts from the repo once safe, relying on .gitignore and regenerated fixtures instead.

Definition of done:
- cargo test -p mcp-agent-mail-conformance does not dirty the repo.
- When fixture regeneration is needed, output paths are explicit and default to /tmp, not under the repo.

title: [epic] AgentMailTUI v2: FrankentUI super-console + global mail intelligence
description:
## Background
`br-1m6a` and `br-10wc` shipped a strong first-generation FrankentUI console and 8-screen operations TUI. That closed the baseline gap versus plain logs, but operators are still blocked by major UX/feature parity gaps.

## Remaining Gap (why this epic exists)
The current Rust implementation is still short of the target in five critical ways:
1. Dashboard information density and composition are below FrankentUI showcase quality, especially on large terminals.
2. Layout behavior is not yet truly reactive/adaptive across tiny, normal, and ultra-wide terminal footprints.
3. Search UX is functional but not yet equivalent to showcase-grade exploratory workflows with rich filtering and preview ergonomics.
4. Full Python web UI externally observed functionality is not yet explicit, test-gated parity in this plan.
5. Static export workflows (GitHub Pages + Cloudflare Pages) are not yet first-class, conformance-tested deliverables.

## Goal
Build AgentMailTUI v2 + Web parity as a showcase-grade, operator-first control center that combines:
- global mail intelligence across projects,
- high-fidelity markdown-first reading,
- reactive FrankentUI dashboards/widgets,
- and complete Python web UI + static export parity.

## Product Outcomes
- Faster triage: operators can locate, read, and act on critical communication in seconds.
- Better situational awareness: high-signal metrics and anomaly widgets stay visible without wasting screen real estate.
- Better trust: deterministic behavior, explicit parity contracts, strong tests, and enforceable performance budgets.
- Better deployment flexibility: identical observed behavior across TUI, web UI, and static-export surfaces.

## Definition of Done
- Global search and exploration workflows are practical on multi-project production-scale datasets.
- Message/thread preview surfaces provide readable, safe, styled markdown in terminal and web.
- FrankentUI widgets materially improve insight density and actionability with responsive behavior.
- Python web UI functionality is matched in Rust with conformance evidence.
- Static export to GitHub Pages and Cloudflare Pages is production-usable and fully tested.
- Comprehensive unit + integration + snapshot + PTY + scripted E2E coverage exists for each major track.
- E2E/regression suites emit forensic logs/artifacts (transcripts, traces, metrics, visual diffs) sufficient for root-cause analysis.
- Perf budgets are enforced in CI with trend visibility and explicit release gates.
- Operator docs and rollout gates are complete.

## Notes for Future Contributors
This epic is intentionally self-contained: children include architecture decisions, implementation tracks, testing, perf, docs, rollout controls, and parity governance so future sessions never need to reconstruct intent from external plans.
acceptance_criteria:

- All child tracks under `br-3vwi` are completed with acceptance criteria satisfied.

title: [track] Comprehensive V2 test matrix (unit/snapshot/PTY/E2E)
description:
## Purpose
Define and implement a comprehensive quality net so V2 can evolve quickly without regressions, including parity obligations for TUI, web UI, and static export surfaces.

## Scope
- Unit, integration, snapshot, PTY, browser-E2E, and script-driven end-to-end test layers.
- Rich fixture generation (multi-project, high-volume, pathological markdown, permission edge cases).
- Detailed artifact/logging strategy for debugging CI failures.
- Fault-injection and performance-regression scripts for hardening.
- Web UI parity suites against Python externally observed behavior.
- Static export conformance suites for GitHub Pages and Cloudflare Pages outputs.

## Mandatory Logging Contract
Every E2E/regression suite under this track must emit:
1. human-readable terminal/browser transcript,
2. structured metrics/traces JSON,
3. scenario metadata (seed/config/version/terminal profile/browser profile),
4. failure-focused diagnostics (diffs, stack traces, selected screen dumps, HTML snapshots when applicable).

## Outcome
A deterministic and explainable test matrix that captures correctness, UX regressions, parity regressions, and performance/reliability regressions with sufficient forensic detail to debug quickly.
acceptance_criteria:
## Acceptance Criteria
- Unit/integration/snapshot/PTY/browser-E2E/scripted-E2E suites are implemented and passing.
- Test suites emit transcript + metrics + trace + diagnostic artifact bundles.
- Failure triage is reproducible from captured artifacts.
- Coverage includes correctness, UX, parity (Python web behavior), performance, and fault-recovery behaviors.
- Static export outputs are validated for deterministic structure, working navigation, and search behavior on GH/CF Pages targets.\n- Test matrix includes widget-level unit coverage for the canonical widget catalog plus scripted breakpoint-cycling resize E2E with deterministic logs.

title: [track] Python web UI parity + static export platform (GH Pages + Cloudflare Pages)

- Full parity map for routes, list/detail views, filtering behavior, markdown rendering, actions, and diagnostics.

## Non-Negotiable Constraint
No deliberate behavior drift from Python web UI unless explicitly approved and documented with migration rationale.

## Testability
- Parity conformance suites for Python-vs-Rust observed behavior.
- Browser E2E and snapshot tests for core web workflows.
- Static-export conformance tests for route integrity, search behavior, and deterministic artifact hashing.
- Startup/handshake conformance tests for fixed default endpoint and client initialization compatibility.
acceptance_criteria:

- Existing client configurations targeting `http://127.0.0.1:8765/mcp/` initialize successfully without transport/path surprises.
- Unit/integration/browser-E2E/export-conformance suites pass with forensic logging artifacts.
- Rollout gates require parity evidence before declaring this track complete.

title: Dev UX: am runner script + /api<->/mcp HTTP path alias
description:
## Problem
Running the local HTTP server currently requires multiple manual exports (bearer token from a separate envfile, HTTP_PATH override, LOG_RICH_ENABLED) and is error-prone. In this environment some clients expect /mcp/ while the server defaults to /api/.

## Goals
- One easy entrypoint: am serve starts the server with sane defaults and rich console enabled by default.
- Auto-load HTTP_BEARER_TOKEN from a dev envfile (default: ~/mcp_agent_mail/.env) if not already set.
- Support BOTH /api/ and /mcp/ for the MCP HTTP endpoint (alias each other so either client works).
- Keep backward compatibility for existing E2E scripts that hardcode /api/.

## Implementation
1) Add scripts/am shell wrapper:
- am serve (default) runs: cargo run -p mcp-agent-mail -- serve --host 127.0.0.1 --port 8765
- Defaults: HTTP_PATH=/mcp/ and LOG_RICH_ENABLED=true
- Options: --path mcp|api, --env-file <path>, --host, --port, --no-auth
- If HTTP_BEARER_TOKEN is unset, attempt to read it from env file (strip quotes).

2) Server: accept /api and /mcp as synonyms for the MCP base path:
- If configured base is /api, also accept requests under /mcp by rewriting the request path to the configured base before passing to HttpRequestHandler (configured with base_path=config.http_path).
- If configured base is /mcp, also accept /api similarly.
- Do not change behavior for arbitrary nested bases (for example /api/mcp).

3) Docs: update README.md with scripts/am usage and the /api + /mcp alias note.

## Tests
- Unit tests for the alias path logic (path_allowed + canonicalization).

## Acceptance Criteria
- scripts/am serve works without manual exports in a typical dev setup (token file present).
- With default config (HTTP_PATH unset), both POST /api/ and POST /mcp/ reach the MCP handler.
- Full quality gates pass: cargo fmt --check, cargo check --all-targets, cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings, cargo test.
close_reason: Completed: scripts/am added, /api<->/mcp aliasing wired + tests, README updated, quality gates green.
